ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned many new details about observational astronomy, primarily using optical telescopes. This includes foundational knowledge at every step, from atmosphere to telescope to reduction.
Very basic theory behind observational astronomy.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The material and lectures were great. The workload and difficulty level were appropriate. A minor complaint would be that since the course did not have a textbook, the slides were sparse, and written notes weren't posted, if we missed something from lecture there weren't other resources to use.

Professor Van Dokkum does a nice job at explaining the topics selected for this course. However, the vast majority of topics in this course I picked up along the way or as a TA for YSPA - a high school program hosted at Yale. I would have liked to spend a lot more time with a lot more instruction on how to do real science (i.e. more problem sets on analyzing images like the final project but with more concrete goals).
The design of the class was pretty poor in general.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. The course is very, very important for astronomy. There is no excuse for an astronomer to not take it.

These are very important skills to astronomers, but the course felt too theoretical and basic. I would recommend this course to beginning graduate students, a more rigorous and practical version of this course to advanced undergraduate students, and experience in observing/analysis of raw observational data for graduate students in lieu of this course.
